message_1:
Suppose you are given the following data on the weight and height of 25 individuals: 

Weight (kg) | Height (cm)
--- | ---
70 | 170
68 | 165
75 | 175
83 | 180
62 | 160
70 | 175
67 | 165
78 | 180
85 | 182
59 | 160
71 | 170
74 | 172
80 | 175
72 | 178
77 | 177
63 | 162
72 | 173
79 | 176
76 | 174
68 | 165
73 | 177
69 | 165
84 | 182
81 | 178
70 | 171

Using discriminant analysis, determine whether weight or height is a better predictor of whether an individual is male or female.
message_2:
To perform discriminant analysis, we first need to know the gender of the individuals in the dataset. However, since the gender information is not provided, we cannot perform discriminant analysis to determine whether weight or height is a better predictor of gender.

If the gender information was provided, we could perform linear discriminant analysis (LDA) or quadratic discriminant analysis (QDA) to determine which variable (weight or height) is a better predictor of gender. The one with the higher discriminant function score would be considered the better predictor.
